results.headline: A Woman With a Son, but Not a Country
results.summary_short: “Illegal,” by Olivier Masset-Depasse, follows the desperate struggles of an immigrant trying to stay in her adopted land.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Illégal

results.headline: Labor Strife? Send in the Boss’s Wife
results.summary_short: Catherine Deneuve and Gérard Depardieu join forces in the 1970s-era comedy “Potiche,” about a trophy wife who must run the family business.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Potiche

results.headline: A Son’s Quest, With Nature as a Guide
results.summary_short: With “Bal” (“Honey”), the Turkish director Semih Kaplanoglu enables the lush mountain forests of Rize Province, near the Black Sea, to express what its young protagonist cannot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bal

results.headline: Through the Looking Glass of History
results.summary_short: “My Perestroika” lets you learn the history of a place from the people who lived it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Perestroika

results.headline: ‘The Music Never Stopped,’ by Jim Kohlberg
results.summary_short: “The Music Never Stopped” is about a father and son, separated by bitterness and memory loss, who try to reconcile through music.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Music Never Stopped

results.headline: ‘The Butcher, the Chef and the Swordsman’
results.summary_short: “The Butcher, the Chef and the Swordsman,” directed by Wuershan, entwines three stories, using a dizzying style.
results.display_title: The Butcher, the Chef, and the Swordsman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Butcher, the Chef, and the Swordsman

results.headline: ‘I Am’ by the Director Tom Shadyac
results.summary_short: “I Am,” a documentary by Tom Shadyac, looks to shed light on some big questions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am

results.headline: Riding the Wave of Life’s Indignities
results.summary_short: Paul Giamatti plays a struggling suburbanite facing the usual material and moral anxieties in “Win Win,” Tom McCarthy’s funny and warmhearted new film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Win Win

results.headline: Story of a Jewish Boy
results.summary_short: “The Gift to Stalin,” set in the Kazakh steppe in 1949, tells the story of a Jewish boy who escaped death in a purge and is taken in by an aging railway worker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Gift to Stalin

results.headline: Chile’s Past Is Present in the Desert
results.summary_short: “Nostalgia for the Light” is the director Patricio Guzmán’s cinematic essay on the search for both our cosmic origins and disappeared political prisoners.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nostalgia For The Light

results.headline: Teenager Encounters Adulthood and Nazis
results.summary_short: Martin Koolhoven’s “Winter in Wartime,” set in a village in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands, is an adaptation of a semiautobiographical 1972 novel by Jan Terlouw.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winter in Wartime

results.headline: Operating on the Margins of Pay-to-Play Justice
results.summary_short: Matthew McConaughey plays a Los Angeles shyster in “The Lincoln Lawyer,” adapted from Michael Connelly’s crime novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lincoln Lawyer

results.headline: Calm Down, People; He Comes in Peace
results.summary_short: An extraterrestrial and his human friends hit the road, seeing the best and worst America and its clichés have to offer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paul

results.headline: ‘Motherland,’ the Debut of Doris Yeung
results.summary_short: In “Motherland,” the director Doris Yeung’s debut feature, a Chinese-American woman returns home to investigate a murder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Motherland

results.headline: ‘Desert Flower’ Tells Story of Waris Dirie
results.summary_short: “Desert Flower” is about Waris Dirie, the model from Somalia who became a United Nations spokeswoman against female genital mutilation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desert Flower

results.headline: At Desolate Girls’ School, Diving Teacher Rules Roost
results.summary_short: “Cracks,” a gothically moody girls’ school drama adapted from a Sheila Kohler novel, verges on a horror film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cracks

results.headline: A Simple Prescription for Superior Powers
results.summary_short: An aspiring novelist finds a pharmaceutical cure for writer’s block. But does he use this bounty to write more books?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Limitless

results.headline: ‘Bereavement’ by Stevan Mena
results.summary_short: “Bereavement” finds its delights in excruciating acts of violence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bereavement

results.headline: Irish Feet Aflutter, Stepping Into an Extra Dimension
results.summary_short: The 3-D film version of Michael Flatley’s popular stage show “Lord of the Dance” gives viewers this Irish dancing spectacle in an extra dimension.

results.headline: Capturing a ‘Look at Me’ Milieu With Impish Modesty
results.summary_short: Richard Press’s documentary “Bill Cunningham New York” follows that “On the Street” fashion photographer of The New York Times.
